title: Business Partner Split: Dividing and Selling High Value Bottles
metaTitle: Business Partner Split: Selling Wine and Spirits | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: How to handle wine and spirits when business partners split. Covers documentation, avoiding disputes, getting neutral valuations, and selling efficiently.
summary: When business partners split, dividing shared assets like wine and spirits collections can become complicated. A neutral sale often makes the division simpler and cleaner.

sections.heading: What to Do Next
content: Determine what the partnership agreement says about asset division. If bottles were purchased with business funds, they are business assets.
Getting a neutral valuation helps partners agree on fair division. One partner can buy out the other, or the collection can be sold and proceeds divided.
list: Review partnership agreement regarding asset division
Confirm who has authority to sell or receive offers
Document the collection with photos and inventory
Get a neutral offer to establish value
Decide whether to sell or have one partner buy out the other

sections.heading: What Information Matters for Pricing
content: We provide offers based on current market value. This gives both partners a neutral basis for discussion.
list: Producer names and vintages
Quantities and bottle sizes
Storage conditions
Original packaging or wood cases
Any purchase documentation or records

sections.heading: Common Mistakes to Avoid
content: Letting disputes delay the sale can be costly if storage fees apply or if bottles need to be moved.
Piecemeal division where each partner takes bottles can lead to disagreements about relative values.
list: Dividing bottles without establishing equal values
Delaying while paying storage costs
Selling without partner agreement or authorization
Discarding original packaging
Using valuations based on retail prices instead of what buyers pay

sections.heading: How the Process Works
content: We provide a written offer that both partners can review. This serves as a neutral market valuation.
list: Submit photos and inventory through our form or text to 213-770-9463
We provide a written offer within one to three business days
Share the offer with all partners for discussion
If you decide to sell, confirm authorization and we coordinate logistics
Payment is issued after we receive and verify the bottles

sections.heading: Privacy and Safety Notes
content: The offer we provide is confidential and can be shared among partners as needed.
We provide documentation suitable for partnership dissolution records.
We do not take sides in disputes. Our role is to provide fair market value and handle the transaction if you choose to sell.

faqs.question: Do both partners need to agree to the sale?
faqs.answer: We confirm authorization before proceeding. Typically both partners should agree, or one partner should have documented authority to sell partnership assets.

faqs.question: Can one partner use your offer to buy out the other?
faqs.answer: Yes. Our offer represents fair market value. One partner can pay that amount to the other to keep the collection.

faqs.question: What if partners disagree about whether to sell?
faqs.answer: We can provide a valuation for discussion purposes. You are not obligated to sell. Sometimes having a concrete number helps partners reach agreement.

faqs.question: How do we split payment?
faqs.answer: We issue payment to the authorized seller. Division between partners is handled according to your agreement.

faqs.question: What if the collection is at one partner's location?
faqs.answer: We can pick up from wherever the collection is located. Coordinate access with whoever controls the storage location.

faqs.question: How long is the offer valid?
faqs.answer: We specify validity when we provide the offer. Typically offers are valid for two to four weeks. If you need more time to reach agreement, let us know.
